```{=css}
.blue { color: #00C;}
.green { color: #0D0;}
.darkgreen { color: #060;}
.red { color: #C00;}
.orange { color: #F60;}
.purple { color: #606;}

```

<p>Unlike Snap<em>!</em>, which is a <strong>general purpose</strong>
programming language that can be used to develop a variety of
algorithms, HTML is a <strong>special purpose</strong> programming
language; it's designed for one specific task: designing web pages. HTML
controls the layout and style of text and images on a webpage, but it
doesn't allow for real programming like Snap<em>!</em> does. People use
other languages like JavaScript to program algorithms into websites.</p>

<p>The fundamental skeleton of every HTML webpage looks like the code
below. Browsers use HTTP to turn the HTML into the site you see. Notice
that most of the <strong>HTML tags</strong> (like `\<head\>`)
have a closing tag (like `\</head\>`) designating the end,
and the relevant content goes between the two tags. (The color and
ms-4ation improve readability but are not necessary.)</p>

```{=html}
<pre class="ms-4" style="width:800px"><span class="purple">&lt;!DOCTYPE html&gt;</span>
<span class="blue">&lt;html&gt;</span>
<span class="red">&lt;head&gt;</span>
<span class="orange">&lt;title&gt;</span>The Page Title Goes Here<span class="orange">&lt;/title&gt;</span>
<span class="red">&lt;/head&gt;</span>
<span class="darkgreen">&lt;body&gt;</span>
The page content goes here.
<span class="darkgreen">&lt;/body&gt;</span>
<span class="blue">&lt;/html&gt;</span></pre>
```
